nodes.text: package was introduced to provide a cleaner way, than the use of channels, of managing cancellation and timeouts across goroutines.
While the scope, and API footprint of the package is pretty small, it was a welcome addition to the language when introduced.
type, which carries deadlines, cancellation signals, and other request-scoped values across API boundaries and between processes.

Context is, mostly, used for controlling concurrent subsystems in your application. This week we will cover the different kinds of behavior with contexts including canceling, timeouts, and values. We'll also see how we can clean up a lot of code involving channels by using contexts.
, consists of four methods. These methods provide us the ability to listen for cancellation and timeout events, retrieve values from the context hierarchy, and finally, a way to check what
, if any, caused the context to be canceled.
interface implements several of the channel patterns we have already seen, such as have a
channel that can be listened to for cancellation.
We will cover each of these methods in more detail later. For now, let's briefly look at each one of them.
, can be used to check if a context has a cancellation deadline set, and if so, what that deadline is.
, can be used to listen for cancellation events. This is similar to how we can listen for a channel being closed, but it is more flexible.
, can be used to check if a context has been canceled.
, can be used to retrieve values from the context hierarchy.
package provides a number of useful helper functions for wrapping a
making the need for custom implementations of the
While often we might be given a
, we might also be the one start a
. The most common way to provide a quick and easy way to start a

$ go doc context.Background

package context // import "context"

func Background() Context
    Background returns a non-nil, empty Context. It is never canceled, has no
    values, and has no deadline. It is typically used by the main function,
    initialization, and tests, and as the top-level Context for incoming
    requests.

$ go doc context.Background

package context // import "context"

func Background() Context
    Background returns a non-nil, empty Context. It is never canceled, has no
    values, and has no deadline. It is typically used by the main function,
    initialization, and tests, and as the top-level Context for incoming
    requests.
. As we can see from the output, the context is empty.

function provides default implementation of the
documentation there are rules that must be followed when using the
Programs that use Contexts should follow these rules to keep interfaces consistent across packages and enable static analysis tools to check context propagation.
Do not store Contexts inside a struct type; instead, pass a Context explicitly to each function that needs it. The Context should be the first parameter, typically named ctx.
Context, even if a function permits it. Pass
if you are unsure about which Context to use.
Use context Values only for request-scoped data that transits processes and APIs, not for passing optional parameters to functions.
The same Context may be passed to functions running in different goroutines; Contexts are safe for simultaneous use by multiple goroutines.
is not meant to be stored and held onto, but should be passed at "runtime".
Consider an HTTP request. An HTTP request is a

value that gets passed along through the application until eventually the response is returned. We would not want to store, or hold on to, the request for future use as it would be of no benefit once the response is returned.
in our code behaves like the HTTP request. We pass a
through the application where they can be listened to for cancellation, or for other purposes, at "runtime".
is passed through the application, a receiving method may wrap the context with their cancellation functionality or with
to add a value, such as a "request id", before passing the
along to any functions, or methods, that it may call.
The result is a nodal hierarchy of
values that starts at the beginning of the request, or the start of the application, and spiders out throughout the application.
functions. Each function wraps the given
with a new one before either passing it along to the next function or returning.

As we have seen one feature of the
package is that it allows you to pass request specific values to the next function in the chain.
This provide a lot of useful benefits, such as passing request or session specific values, such as the request id, user id of the requestor, etc. to the next function in the chain.
Using values, however, has its disadvantages, as we will see shortly.
function can be used to wrap a given
that contains the given key/value pair.

$ go doc context.WithValue

package context // import "context"

func WithValue(parent Context, key, val any) Context
    WithValue returns a copy of parent in which the value associated with key is
    val.

    Use context Values only for request-scoped data that transits processes and
    APIs, not for passing optional parameters to functions.

    The provided key must be comparable and should not be of type string or any
    other built-in type to avoid collisions between packages using context.
    Users of WithValue should define their own types for keys. To avoid
    allocating when assigning to an interface{}, context keys often have
    concrete type struct{}. Alternatively, exported context key variables'
    static type should be a pointer or interface.

$ go doc context.WithValue

package context // import "context"

    Users of WithValue should define their own types for keys. To avoid

    static type should be a pointer or interface.
as its first argument, and a key and a value as its second and third arguments.

keys our package or application uses, we run the risk of a malicious agent stealing, or modifying our values. For example, in a web request we might set a
at the beginning of the request, but a piece of middleware later in the chain might modify that value to something else.

While having the ability to pass contextual information via the
is useful, the real benefit, and design of the
package, is that it can be used to propagate cancellation events to those listening to the context. When a parent
is canceled, all its children are also canceled.
, we must have a way of cancelling it. The

$ go doc context.WithCancel

package context // import "context"

func WithCancel(parent Context) (ctx Context, cancel CancelFunc)
    WithCancel returns a copy of parent with a new Done channel. The returned
    context's Done channel is closed when the returned cancel function is called
    or when the parent context's Done channel is closed, whichever happens
    first.

    Canceling this context releases resources associated with it, so code should
    call cancel as soon as the operations running in this Context complete.

$ go doc context.WithCancel

package context // import "context"

func WithCancel(parent Context) (ctx Context, cancel CancelFunc)
    WithCancel returns a copy of parent with a new Done channel. The returned
    context's Done channel is closed when the returned cancel function is called
    or when the parent context's Done channel is closed, whichever happens
    first.

    Canceling this context releases resources associated with it, so code should
    call cancel as soon as the operations running in this Context complete.
function returns a second argument, that of a
function, which can be used to cancel the
There a few things that need to be noted about the
. So let's examine each in more detail.

$ go doc context.CancelFunc

package context // import "context"

type CancelFunc func()
    A CancelFunc tells an operation to abandon its work. A CancelFunc does not
    wait for the work to stop. A CancelFunc may be called by multiple goroutines
    simultaneously. After the first call, subsequent calls to a CancelFunc do
    nothing.

$ go doc context.CancelFunc

package context // import "context"

type CancelFunc func()
    A CancelFunc tells an operation to abandon its work. A CancelFunc does not
    wait for the work to stop. A CancelFunc may be called by multiple goroutines
    simultaneously. After the first call, subsequent calls to a CancelFunc do
    nothing.
"After the first call, subsequent calls to a CancelFunc do nothing".
. That is, calling it multiple times has no effect beyond the first call.

ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
cancel() // cancels the context
cancel() // has no effect
cancel() // has no effect
"Canceling this context releases resources associated with it, so code should call cancel as soon as the operations running in this Context complete."

In addition to allowing us to manually cancel a
package also provides mechanisms for creating a
that will self-cancel after, or at, a given time. Using these mechanics allows us to control how long to run some before we give up and assume that the operation has failed.
package provides two functions for creating time based, self-cancelling, a

$ go doc context.WithDeadline

package context // import "context"

func WithDeadline(parent Context, d time.Time) (Context, CancelFunc)
    WithDeadline returns a copy of the parent context with the deadline
    adjusted to be no later than d. If the parent's deadline is already earlier
    than d, WithDeadline(parent, d) is semantically equivalent to parent.
    The returned context's Done channel is closed when the deadline expires,
    when the returned cancel function is called, or when the parent context's
    Done channel is closed, whichever happens first.

    Canceling this context releases resources associated with it, so code should
    call cancel as soon as the operations running in this Context complete.

$ go doc context.WithDeadline

package context // import "context"

func WithDeadline(parent Context, d time.Time) (Context, CancelFunc)
    WithDeadline returns a copy of the parent context with the deadline
    adjusted to be no later than d. If the parent's deadline is already earlier
    than d, WithDeadline(parent, d) is semantically equivalent to parent.
    The returned context's Done channel is closed when the deadline expires,
    when the returned cancel function is called, or when the parent context's
    Done channel is closed, whichever happens first.

    Canceling this context releases resources associated with it, so code should
    call cancel as soon as the operations running in this Context complete.
should be cancelled. That means we need an exact date/time we want this

and use it to create a
that will self-cancel at that date and time.

Listening for System Signals with Context
Previously, when discussing channels, we saw how to capture system signals, such as
as an argument. In return, we are given a
that will be canceled when the signal is received.

$ go doc os/signal.NotifyContext

package signal // import "os/signal"

func NotifyContext(parent context.Context, signals ...os.Signal) (ctx context.Context, stop context.CancelFunc)
    NotifyContext returns a copy of the parent context that is marked done (its
    Done channel is closed) when one of the listed signals arrives, when the
    returned stop function is called, or when the parent context's Done channel
    is closed, whichever happens first.

    The stop function unregisters the signal behavior, which, like signal.Reset,
    may restore the default behavior for a given signal. For example,
    the default behavior of a Go program receiving os.Interrupt is to exit.
    Calling NotifyContext(parent, os.Interrupt) will change the behavior to
    cancel the returned context. Future interrupts received will not trigger the
    default (exit) behavior until the returned stop function is called.

    The stop function releases resources associated with it, so code should call
    stop as soon as the operations running in this Context complete and signals
    no longer need to be diverted to the context.

$ go doc os/signal.NotifyContext

package signal // import "os/signal"

func NotifyContext(parent context.Context, signals ...os.Signal) (ctx context.Context, stop context.CancelFunc)
    NotifyContext returns a copy of the parent context that is marked done (its
    Done channel is closed) when one of the listed signals arrives, when the
    returned stop function is called, or when the parent context's Done channel
    is closed, whichever happens first.

    The stop function unregisters the signal behavior, which, like signal.Reset,
    may restore the default behavior for a given signal. For example,
    the default behavior of a Go program receiving os.Interrupt is to exit.
    Calling NotifyContext(parent, os.Interrupt) will change the behavior to
    cancel the returned context. Future interrupts received will not trigger the
    default (exit) behavior until the returned stop function is called.

    The stop function releases resources associated with it, so code should call
    stop as soon as the operations running in this Context complete and signals
    no longer need to be diverted to the context.
that will cancel when the signal is received. It also returns a
that can be used to cancel

nodes.text: Testing system signals is tricky and care must be taken not to accidentally exit your running tests. Unfortunately, the
package does not provide a "test" signal, or a way to implement a test signal.
in our tests as these are allocated to the developer to use for their own purposes.
When we are testing signals, we are testing a

signal, that will caught by anyone else who is listening to that signal. Because of this we want to make that when testing signals we aren't running the tests in parallel and that we don't have other tests also listening to the same signal.
. How do we test that the
function will respond properly to a signal? We don't want to make that the responsibility of the
that it can listen to for cancellation. The

function doesn't care why it was told to stop listening, it just needs to stop listening. This could be because we receive an interrupt signal, because a deadline has passed, or because the application no longer needs the

nodes.name: func

nodes.text: that will self-cancel after 5 seconds if nothing else happens. We then wrap that
function, that will self-cancel when the system receives a
to be cancelled, and then respond accordingly.

nodes.name: example

nodes.text: Inside the test, in a goroutine, we can trigger the
signal by sending it to the current process,

nodes.name: kill

nodes.text:
$ go test -v

=== RUN   Test_Signals
    signals_test.go:46: SignalCtx([]os.Signal{31})
        	--> WithCancel
        		--> WithTimeout(deadline: {wall:13909887566670467024 ext:5000672626 loc:0x1002327c0})
        			--> Background
    signals_test.go:15: waiting for context to finish
    signals_test.go:58: sending test signal
    signals_test.go:70: signal received
    signals_test.go:71: successfully completed
--- PASS: Test_Signals (1.00s)
PASS
ok  	demo	1.725s

$ go test -v

=== RUN   Test_Signals
    signals_test.go:46: SignalCtx([]os.Signal{31})
        	--> WithCancel
        		--> WithTimeout(deadline: {wall:13909887566670467024 ext:5000672626 loc:0x1002327c0})
        			--> Background
    signals_test.go:15: waiting for context to finish
    signals_test.go:58: sending test signal
    signals_test.go:70: signal received
    signals_test.go:71: successfully completed
--- PASS: Test_Signals (1.00s)
PASS
ok  	demo	1.725s

nodes.title: Listening for System Signals with Context

nodes.text: In this chapter we explore the concept of contexts in Go. We learn that contexts are a way to manage cancellation, timeouts, and other request-scoped values across API boundaries and between processes. We also learn how to use contexts to clean up a lot of code involving channels, such as listening for system signals. We discussed the nodal hierarchy of how the
. We learned the different was to cancel a
s to confirm shutdown behavior. The
package, while small, is a very powerful tool for managing concurrency in your application.
